attributes.action: Make railcards accessible to all to reduce the cost of public transport.
attributes.background: Currently railcard access ends at the age of 30 until the age of 60, unless specific circumstances. These ages are completely arbitrary and all should be granted access to a railcard if they see the benefit. This makes public transport cheaper which reduces road traffic and carbon emissions.
attributes.additional_details: There should be a railcard available for people between the ages of 30 and 60.

attributes.action: Ban the burning of peat for fuel
attributes.background: The government should ban the use of peat as fuel. Instead, the government should support the development of sustainable energy sources. Peatlands should be protected from harvesting for any reason, not just for horticulture.
attributes.additional_details: The recent announcement to ban peat in horticulture is a positive step for protecting peatlands. But a significant proportion of peat is harvested for use as fuel to burn. This still results in peatlands being destroyed and increases carbon emissions.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Create a ‘Day of Rest’ in each calendar week as we come out lockdown.
attributes.background: The lockdown has proved that we as a nation can not only survive but also thrive when we’re forced to Slow down and bring about a natural pause or stop in our busy lives. The environment and wild animal species have been allowed in many respects to return to ‘their normal’ as pollution levels drop.
attributes.additional_details:
To return to having a day of rest where planes, trains and transport systems were halted for 24hrs, where businesses and schools  re charged through ‘stopping’ and allowed employees and pupils to rejuvenate or work from home.
Carbon emissions targets would surely be more obtainable.
This doesn’t have to be based on the old model of a religious day of rest, but of course those who wish to return to still contemplation and prayer could do so. It would be more powerful as an international movement.

attributes.action: UK Government: restrict reduced VAT on domestic energy to renewable sources only
attributes.background: Apply the reduced VAT rate on energy consumption - currently 5% - only where supplies of that energy derive from a renewable source.
attributes.additional_details: To demonstrate that the UK is serious about reaching net-zero carbon emissions by 2050.

attributes.action: Ban the importation of wood pellets used for the generation of electricity.
attributes.background: Importation of wood pellets should be banned and the use in power stations should be urgently reviewed. Burning of wood pellets must not be considered sustainable or a means of meeting net zero targets. Billions of UK green subsidies into this technology must stop.
attributes.additional_details: Using wood pellets releases more CO2 than burning coal. Because the government considers wood pellets as a renewable resource, by re-planting trees, the emissions are classed as carbon neutral and “helps” to get closer to the neutral target in 2030. This is not the case. Deforestation is happening around the world to supply the UK with wood pellets for burning, which generates around 11% of our energy needs. British taxpayers are funding this destruction of forests.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Ban all advertising of carbon-emitting SUVs in the UK
attributes.background: The extraordinary growth of carbon-emitting SUVs has contributed hugely to global car emissions (almost entirely cancelling out carbon gains made by the growth of Electric Vehicles) and these cars add to poor air quality that studies show kills tens of thousands each year.
attributes.additional_details:
Cigarette ads are rightly banned, and there is no reason why car manufacturers should be allowed to continue to promote carbon-emitting and polluting SUVs.

In 1965, amidst growing concern over the impacts that smoking had on health, advertising cigarettes on TV was banned in the UK. By 2005 all promotion had been banned, and smoking has declined as a result. Yet we still allow car manufacturers to promote carbon-emitting SUVs that impact air quality and contribute to carbon emissions. Why? In line with sensible precedent on banning advertising to drive down smoking, this government should ban all promotions of SUVs.

departments.name: Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport

attributes.action: Require all newly built homes to be Carbon Neutral by 2030
attributes.background: The Government should require all new build homes to be Carbon Neutral, using eco materials, solar panels, and planting trees etc. All materials/resources should have their carbon impact measure and then offset by appropriate means.
attributes.additional_details: Land is being purchased and built on at an alarming rate. Animals are losing their habitats and very little is being done to combat the carbon which will be absorbed by these trees/ fields which are being dug up. Builders should be made responsible for combating the additional carbon which will be released into the environment. The increase in new houses is also linked to the increase in quarries and mining which also increases carbon emission.

departments.name: Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities

attributes.action: Apply a carbon tax to all imported food that is proportional to food miles
attributes.background: The Government recently rejected proposals for a 'meat tax' proposed as a way of cutting carbon emissions. This was great news, as it could have harmed British farmers and the climate. A plant-based diet can be more harmful than a mixed diet if fruit and veg are imported and not grown domestically.
attributes.additional_details: This tax would encourage purchase of locally produced, seasonally available food. This will help support British farmers (who produce, on average, 2.5 times less CO2 than the global average) and reduce fossil fuels used to import food. Burning fossil fuels releases CO2 into the atmosphere, but the CO2 emitted raising meat and dairy animals can form part of a carbon cycle. The grasslands they live on are carbon sinks, such that some livestock farms are close to achieving carbon neutrality.

attributes.action: Increase tax on private flights
attributes.background: Significantly increase taxes on private flights, to discourage use of private flights and to encourage use of more sustainable and less environmentally damaging modes of transport.
attributes.additional_details: Do this to help protect the environment by  promoting positive behaviour to reduce carbon emissions to address the climate change emergency.

attributes.action: Members of Parliament should have to declare their carbon emissions
attributes.background: The House of Commons should establish an Independent Regulatory Body that monitors the level of carbon emitted by MPs while carrying out their official work.
attributes.additional_details:
This would be publicly available like their expenses and interests are currently. It would work by using a specific model for each mode of transport.

The Government should do it to ensure that the 2019 net zero emissions by 2050 target is achieved. Parliament should be taking a lead on issues like this. This would enable the public to see what MPs have been emitting while carrying out their work and gives them the opportunity to scrutinise or praise our politicians. Inevitably, this will lead to a reduction in carbon emissions by MPs. If the country is going to be carbon neutral by 2050 then our policy makers need to be the ones taking the first steps.

attributes.action: Call for global crisis talks for a solution to end the destruction of the Amazon
attributes.background: Seek to hold a crisis meeting between the leaders of all nations, to come up with an international solution to the catastrophic destruction of the Amazon Rainforest which we are seeing.
attributes.additional_details: As leaders on the world stage, the UK government need to step up and be proactive as a matter of urgency. The reason is simple - lives of UK citizens and indeed all life on Earth is at risk due to the unprecedented destruction being caused by fires burning there. All life on Earth is dependent on a thriving Amazon Rainforest to provide the oxygen we breathe and absorb carbon created by our greenhouse gas emissions. This is an emergency and it needs to be treated like one.

attributes.action: Call for action at COP26 to ensure carbon emissions never exceed 2019 levels
attributes.background: Following the decline in emissions during the Covid-19 outbreak, at COP26 the Government should call for action which ensures carbon emissions never exceed 2019 levels.
attributes.additional_details: The decline in emissions seen in recent months due to lockdowns across the globe has created an opportunity to ensure that global emissions never exceed levels in 2019. This will require action by governments across the world, and the UK Government should use COP26 to call for this.

attributes.action: Legalise and incentivise uptake of personal electric vehicles
attributes.background: I would like the Government to legalise and create incentives to promote uptake of all personal, micro powered, more carbon efficient vehicles. This could help reduce carbon emissions from personal transport.
attributes.additional_details: This is an issue that requires swift action to take a global lead in changing travel behaviours. Both for global environment and local pollution. The costs of this damage are on record. And in the current fuel and cost of living crisis, many lives could be improved and cities made less polluted and provided with a more mobile work force. We believe the environmental, social and commercial benefits are clear.

attributes.action: For carbon neutrality end the use of gas for heat by domestic properties by 2050
attributes.background: The government should confirm by policy that all domestic properties in the UK should be heated, water and space, by an electric method. Domestic burning of any gas through distribution networks should be stopped, no new domestic gas networks built, and existing gas networks phased out by 2050.
attributes.additional_details: It is critical to reduce the carbon emissions in the UK, quickly, to achieve carbon neutrality by 2050. Burning of any fossil fuel needs to be reduced to ideally zero. Domestic gas burning, even if mixed with hydrogen, still leaves a significant carbon footprint. Gas heating for water, space and cooking can be replaced with efficient electric systems such as heat pumps, solar panels and electric storage heating. At present gas networks have false hope they can continue to operate.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Give solar panels on residential properties legally protected rights to light
attributes.background: The Government should protect rights to light for residential solar panels by:
attributes.additional_details:
1. Extending right to light legislation to include solar panels.
2. Adding caveats to 'Permitted Development' laws to protect solar panels.
3. Ensuring Party Wall Agreements don't affect rights to light of solar panels.

At present I believe the Government's 'GREEN' policies are contradictory They are not fit for purpose because different policies can work against its commitment to carbon emission reduction targets.

departments.name: Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities

attributes.action: Fund further research and development into the production of synthetic fuels
attributes.background: Government needs to cut carbon emissions and the development and use of synthetic fuels could help. Synthetic fuels could help make transport carbon neutral so the Government should fund research and development into synthetic fuels that can be used by current car engines without modification.
attributes.additional_details:
The production of synthetic fuels could help make transport carbon neutral, which would help the UK government reach their carbon dioxide emissions target of the Paris Agreement.
 
Developing synthetic fuel that can be used by existing engines without modification would mean that those who enjoy driving petrol/diesel vehicles would be able to continue doing so in a way that won't threaten the environment.
 
Refueling a car is much more time-efficient than electric cars, and much of the electricity supply used to charge electric vehicles is still produced by fossil fuel power stations.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Remove the need for consent to install double glazing in listed building
attributes.background: We want the Government to enable owners of listed buildings to install slim-profile double glazing, without needing to seek consent for this, provided the new windows are in the same style as the original windows.
attributes.additional_details:
We believe the Government needs to take action to enable people who own and live in a listed building, at a time when energy bills have increased dramatically, to take steps to reduce their energy costs and carbon emissions.
Now that double glazed windows in many suitable styles are available the Government should enable us look after our heritage in an appropriate and environmentally friendly way, without needing to seek consent.

attributes.action: Ban transparent plastic windows from food packaging
attributes.background: Make it mandatory for all UK-based food manufacturers to remove the transparent plastic "windows" on food packaging, as they are often non-recyclable and we believe they are unnecessary, given images of the food contained can be included on the packaging.
attributes.additional_details: We believe this could make a useful contribution to reducing carbon emissions and excess waste in the UK, helping us to reach net zero carbon emissions sooner and help avert climate disaster. Customers could be more at peace of mind knowing that their lunchtime sandwiches are having less of an impact on the earth.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Reduce or remove VAT on the supply, rental & repair of bicycles, inc. e-bikes.
attributes.background: Follow suit with the EU and reduce (or even remove) VAT on the supply, rental and repair of bicycles, including e-bikes. This will encourage more people to cycle and thus reduce carbon emissions, which in turn will improve life in our country and on our planet.
attributes.additional_details: Follow suit with the EU and reduce (or even remove) VAT on the supply, rental and repair of bicycles, including e-bikes. This will encourage more people to cycle and thus reduce carbon emissions, and improve life in our country and on our planet. More movement, less pollution, better health for all. More info at https://www.ecf.com/news-and-events/news/cycling-organisations-achieve-important-victory-eu-consumers-reduced-vat-soon

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/603540

attributes.action: Ban the extraction and use of peat in the UK
attributes.background:
Peat grows so slowly that it's essentially non-renewable.

It's a really important carbon sink, but it's used as heating fuel, which produces pollution and CO2.

It's used in gardening, but renewable and byproduct alternatives are available.

Outlaw peat extraction and use in the UK.
attributes.additional_details:
When the selling and burning of wet wood is outlawed, as happened in England recently, people switch to burning peat among other things: https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/sep/27/pollutionwatch-wood-and-peat-burning-brings-return-of-air-pollution-to-dublin

Peatlands are the largest natural terrestrial carbon store, and damaged peatlands are a major source of greenhouse gas emissions: https://www.iucn.org/resources/issues-briefs/peatlands-and-climate-change

rejection.details:
You might like to sign the following petitions:

Ban the use of peat in horticulture and all growing media by 2023.
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/562054

Ban all extraction of peat for horticulture by 2022.
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/581532

attributes.action: Ban Sport Utility Vehicles (SUVs) from our towns and cities
attributes.background: Restrict the use of SUVs in towns and cities, especially in the main centres and residential areas. Enforce a maximum length and width for vehicles parking on narrow streets and in tight car parks. Allow necessary exemptions for commercial vehicles and those specially adapted for access.
attributes.additional_details:
This recent report from the New Weather Institute https://bit.ly/3uLtTqP shows that the places where SUVs dominate are also where road space is most scarce. Large SUVs are too big for a standard UK parking space, and are some of the most polluting vehicles in terms of air quality and carbon emissions.

SUVs are unsafe. They encourage aggressive driving, and their drivers have less visibility of other road users - particularly children, who may be less tall than the front of the vehicle.

rejection.details: We can't accept your petition because the UK Government and Parliament aren't responsible for the issue you raise. This would be a decision for individual local authorities.

attributes.action: UK to ban the sale and use of all fossil fuels in all settings from 1st Jan 2040
attributes.background: To improve air quality and fulfil the UK's commitment to net zero carbon emissions  by 2050.
attributes.additional_details: To help phase out the use of fossil fuel technologies in all applications throughout the UK.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Reduce Vehicle ROAD TAX
attributes.background: Before 2000 road tax was based on ENGINE SIZE. after 2000 road tax is based on Co2 CARBON EMISSIONS. but the vehicles before 2000s are not environmentally friendly and there Co2 are higher. Since then the new vehicles are environmentally friendly and Co2 are less than vehicles before 2000s.
attributes.additional_details:
Before 2000 road tax was based on ENGINE SIZE. after 2000 road tax is based on Co2 CARBON EMISSIONS. but the vehicles before 2000s are not environmentally friendly and there Co2 are higher. Since then the new vehicles are environmentally friendly and Co2 are less than vehicles before 2000s. So why are we pay more ROAD TAX AND RISING EVERY YEAR. Road tax should be cheaper.
And reduced for life. As new vehicles are environmentally friendly and Co2 way less than vehicles before 2000s vehicles

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We understand you would like to reduce vehicle excise duty for less polluting vehicles, but we're not sure whether you want to cars registered before 2001 to be taxed based on their emissions are or whether you'd like a different change to reduce vehicle tax rates. 

You may wish to sign this petition:
Remove Vehicle Excise Duty and add the cost to Fuel Duty
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/314118
                
You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do.

attributes.action: Remove the need for planning permission to mount solar panels on flat roofs.
attributes.background: Many UK properties have outbuildings with flat roofs that could be used to mount solar panels. These are currently subject to planning laws if the panels extend 20cm from the "plane" of the roof. Mounting them flat to avoid this requirements is inefficient.
attributes.additional_details:
Modify the planning requirements to allow panels to be mounted on a flat roof providing they do not extend above the roof of the main property.
This could allow many more home owners to install Solar panels with far more ease and assist the government in meeting it's targets for reducing carbon emissions. This could also help households in this time of energy uncertainty, increase jobs through supply and demand and reduce the demand on the National Grid.

attributes.action: Introduce a legal right to work from home
attributes.background: In view of the huge increase in home working as a result of the Covid-19 pandemic, we call on the Goverment to amend the Working Time Regulations 1998 to include all work performed from home; at present working from home voluntarily is not normally considered 'working time' under the regulations
attributes.additional_details: Working from home has significant social, economic & environmental benefits. These include less costs for employers, increased efficiency & work/life balance for employees & major environmental benefits, less traffic, air pollutuon, carbon emissions. Germany & Finland have now enshrined home working in law. Over 47% working populaton been working from home during lockdown & Goverment accepts this has reduced spread of covid-19. Home working is here to stay & should be embraced by Government

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/318057

attributes.action: Include electric scooters as EAPC's
attributes.background: Electric scooters are currently illegal on public roads in the UK. They should be added to the EN15194 law. The same law that covers EAPC's, otherwise known as electronic bicycles
attributes.additional_details: If this law were to be updated with the fashionable electronic scooters then we, as a country would have more chance of cutting carbon emissions in the future.

rejection.details:
You may wish to sign some of these petitions calling for similar actions:

Allow 'Personal Electric Vehicles' to use cycle lanes and walkways: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/301014

Make electric scooters legal to reduce our carbon footprint / cut emissions: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/301579

Since you started your petition the Government has launched a consultation for legalising rental e-scooter trails. You can find out more about the Governments proposals here: https://www.gov.uk/government/consultations/legalising-rental-e-scooter-trials-defining-e-scooters-and-rules-for-their-use/legalising-rental-e-scooter-trials

attributes.action: Mandatory carbon emissions traffic light score for all products and services
attributes.background: I want the Government to introduce a carbon emissions traffic light score for product manufacturers, service providers and utility suppliers, to make it clear to consumers (on product packaging and marketing material) what the carbon emissions are for their product or service.
attributes.additional_details:
Global governments and populations are taking notice of the fact that our planet is in danger of suffering the effects of climate change. Each year, leading nations meet to discuss how nations will move forward to help reduce emissions and mitigate the impact.
 
I believe legislation introducing new requirements for product manufacturers, utility suppliers and service providers to display a carbon emission score (whether physically, or digitally), using a traffic light system similar to that for nutritional information, could make a significant impact to driving change.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Legislate against banks continuing to invest in fossil fuels.
attributes.background: Legislate to oblige all banks to transition away from financing the coal, oil and gas industry by 2030.
attributes.additional_details: The commitment at COP26 that financial institutions would reach net-zero by 2050 is far from enough. BankTrack has said that, in order to have only a 50% chance of limiting global heating to below 1.5 degrees, global carbon emissions must be more than halved by 2030. To be possible, banks must stop financing the fossil fuel industry in this decade. This is not happening. Banks around the world have invested over $3 trillion into fossil fuel in the past five years. The time to legislate is now.

rejection.details: We can't accept your petition because the UK Government and Parliament aren't responsible for the issue you raise. The UK Government and Parliament aren't responsible for directing investments by banks.

attributes.action: Protect football clubs from flooding; act now to radically cut carbon emissions.
attributes.background: We demand the government acts fully on the recommendations of their Climate Change Commission.
attributes.additional_details:
25% of league clubs will be regularly flooded by 2050 unless we take urgent action now. 
The United Nations describe the current climate change situation as: "Code Red for Humanity" (IPCC report August 3021).
Watch this short documentary to find out more: https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=NRAusanxXkg

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We understand that you are concerned about climate change and the possible impact that it could have on football clubs, especially through flooding, but we're not sure exactly what you'd like the Government or Parliament to do. We are not sure if you would like to see more funding for football clubs to help them tackle climate change or if you want the Government to fully act on the recommendations of the Climate Change Commission.

You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do.

We currently have the following petitions open that you may like to sign:

Change the zero carbon emission goals to 2025 instead of 2050
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/594359

Fund global climate change mitigation and give displaced people refugee status
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/585989

Take action to tackle global deforestation
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/590280

Ban drilling for fossil fuels and put more money into using renewable energy.
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/591338

Make it mandatory for companies to report all direct and indirect emissions
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/594632

attributes.action: Stop sending plastic waste abroad & increase the UK's plastic recycling capacity
attributes.background: The UK needs to stop sending recyclable plastic waste abroad,  increase its plastic recycling capacity & take responsibility for the amount of (often unnecessary) plastic it generates. Investments should be made into constructing more plastic recycling plants in the UK.
attributes.additional_details: Tens of thousands of tonnes of plastic waste from the UK is sent abroad to countries such as Turkey. These countries do not have the capacity to recycle their own waste. So much of the UK's recyclable plastic waste is being dumped or burnt. This is not good enough. Increasing the UK's plastic recycling capacity would reduce our carbon emissions & reduce habitats across the world from being destroyed by the accumulation of non-biodegradable plastic.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition which calls for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/329233

attributes.action: Pay a contribution towards the maintenance cost of the A38 over the Tamar Bridge
attributes.background: Tamar Bridge is jointly owned by Plymouth City Council and Cornwall Council, providing a vital strategic road link in the South West. With rising costs for maintenance, we would like the Government to financially support the A38 over the bridge, as it does for other major UK strategic routes.
attributes.additional_details: In accordance with the Tamar Bridge Act, the crossing is funded on a “user pays” principle which means that the only source of revenue is toll charges for those who use the bridge. With a reduction in the number of users, which is expected to continue in years ahead, the only option has been to seek a rise in the cost of the toll. This will impact most on those residents who use the bridge daily to commute to work and who may seek alternative routes potentially adding to carbon emissions.

rejection.details:
Petitions must call for a specific action that the UK Government or Parliament are directly responsible for.

Decisions about maintenance of local authority assets are a matter for the relevant local authorities, not the Government or Parliament. We can't accept petitions calling on the Government to provide additional funding to individual local authorities.

attributes.action: Plant 2 Billion Trees so the UK can reach its net neutral carbon target by 2050
attributes.background: Plant 2 billion trees between now and 2050 to help achieve the UK's carbon neutral target.
attributes.additional_details: Today (20/04/21) the government announced a further cut of 78% to the UK's carbon emissions compared to 1990s levels. Yet with every new target announced and scheme introduced to cut emissions, very little seems to be said about actually taking CO2 out of the atmosphere. That is why I and so many others wish to see the government embark on a massive nation wide tree planting scheme, and Parliament legislating for it. Trees are a crucial tool in adsorbing and sequestrating CO2, lets use them!

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for a similar action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/552296

attributes.action: Make work from home a worker's right.
attributes.background: During the Covid-19 pandemic, offices were closed, workers in mass were sent to work from home. This had shown great benefits for workers, businesses and the environment. With modern technology, many workers can work from home and do their job. Work from home should become a modern worker's right.
attributes.additional_details:
Working from home has be found to add great benefit to society at large. More time spent with family and friends due to no longer needing to commute, resulted in greater mental well-being. This is turn reduced stress levels and better child welfare. This is a key step to improving  societal health, and lowering the burden on the NHS.

Emissions have been reduced as less people cram into cars for a daily commute. With the advent of global warming, this helps the U' become carbon neutral.

rejection.details: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/318057

attributes.action: Legislation to prevent local authorities introducing rules preventing drop kerbs
attributes.background: We as a country have a goal to reduce carbon emissions. Some local government have rules preventing drop kerb access to driveways. To meet targets the motorists that can switch should be able to.
attributes.additional_details:
We have diesel car, want to switch to Ev. Local government rules prevent us (3ft x4ft grass verge).
Could there be legislation to allow drop kerb access for Environmental purposes.  This would assist switch to EV's to thousands around the UK to do so and help meet targets of reducing emissions. No matter which political party is in control of a region. We all still have a common goal.

rejection.details:
The decision to grant permission to build dropped kerbs is a matter for local councils and not of Parliament or the Government. Local councils allow dropped kerbs to be built in accordance with conditions they set. 

You can petition your local council to change or amend the conditions with which they grant dropped kerb permissions if that is something you would like to see happen.

attributes.action: Legalize the use of personal e-Scooters / PLEV's in cycle lanes.
attributes.background:
Legalize the use of e-scooter / PLEVS (within reason), as to the likes of many other European countries.
Introducing limitations and safety measures will reduce chances of them falling into the wrong/incapable hands.
attributes.additional_details:
They will reduce the carbon footprint, zero emissions.
They will reduce congestion & overcrowded roads.
It is a cheaper alternative to public transport & will reduce chances of COVID-19 transmission between passengers.
They are much safer than bicycles/e-bikes, as they're lighter & much easier to dismount & can be limited/restricted to specified speeds.

rejection.details:
We have published the following petitions, which you might like to sign:

Legalize the use of e-scooters where bikes can be used: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/583107

Allow E-scooters and Electric Skateboards in cycle lanes and on roads: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/578486

attributes.action: Include kg CO2 equivalent produced on all food packaging
attributes.background:
Make it mandatory to display kg CO2 equivalent emissions produced in the manufacturing and shipping of food products on packaging when possible.


The aim is to increase awareness of the issue and to help consumers make informed choices.
attributes.additional_details:
Food accounts for 26% of greenhouse gas emissions globally. 

Lack of easily accessible and understandable information prevents people from making informed choices, and leads to confusion around the environmental impacts of consumer's food choices.

An informed consumer, choosing a low carbon product, would encourage systematic change and promote locally grown food.

Eg, importing 1kg of asparagus from Peru produces 11kg of CO2 compared to 2.1kg of CO2 when produced in the UK.

rejection.details: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/549844

attributes.action: Fit all new homes with solar panels
attributes.background: Pass a order that all developers should fit solar panels on new build houses.
attributes.additional_details: Meet our zero carbon emissions

rejection.details:
We have published the following petitions, which you might like to sign:

New planning regulations on all new houses - climate conscious energy supply: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/594561

Fund free solar panels for all homes: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/588314

attributes.action: Increase percentage of taxpayers money towards public transport.
attributes.background: We want the government to increase the amount of money that is given to public transport in order to reduce bus fares (specifically for secondary school and university students). We hope that this will help to reduce carbon emissions by encouraging more young people to use the bus services.
attributes.additional_details: We would like the government to do this as we believe it will reduce carbon emissions and help with the global issue of climate change. The bus fares at the moment are roughly £450 per person per year which is the highest it’s ever been. We wish for the prices to be lower so that they are more affordable for low income or large families as we believe that everyone deserves the same opportunities.

rejection.details:
We understand you would like to see the price of travelling on public transport go down, but it is unclear how the Government can increase the percentage of taxpayers money going towards public transport. The Department for Transport's budget is formed of tax payer contributions and income from private transport providers (e.g. train operators/franchised rail) and you can read more about where and how it is spent here:
https://researchbriefings.files.parliament.uk/documents/CDP-2018-0050/CDP-2018-0050.pdf

You could start a petition calling for an increase to the budget of the Department for Transport if that is something you would like to see happen.

You may also like to sign the below petitions we currently have open on this topic:

Nationalise all Public Transport and make it free to all to help climate change
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/584793

Fund discounted public transport for under 18s travelling to school
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/590106

attributes.action: Legalise private owned escooters in public places to reduce carbon foot print
attributes.background: Legalise the use of privately owned e scooters in public to reduce emissions and carbon footprint  and apply the same rules as electric pedal bikes
attributes.additional_details: Legalise the use of privately owned e scooters in public to reduce emissions and carbon footprint  and apply the same rules as electric pedal bikes as they are no more dangerous than pedal bikes or electric pedal bikes and they're a great eco friendly way of getting around

rejection.details: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/583107

attributes.action: Stop the national reduction of speed limits as a means to reduce pollution.
attributes.background: Motivate businesses to encourage all employees where it is practical to do so, to work from home.
attributes.additional_details:
The Covid-19 pandemic has shown that technology is available to work effectively from any location with a broadband connection. Technology can be used to reduce our national carbon footprint by changing our traditional habit of committing to and from a place of work.

This approach will provide more time for individuals and families, reduce congestion as well as reduce emissions by removing vehicles from our roads. In addition this will also make cycling on the road safer.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

attributes.action: Demand an End to Investment in New Coal Mines
attributes.background: The Government should intervene immediately to stop a new £165m coal mine in Whitehaven, Cumbria. The proposed mine contradicts our leadership of COP26 and the Government must therefore withdraw planning permission and direct investment to alternative low carbon methods of producing British steel.
attributes.additional_details: The Woodhouse Colliery site in Whitehaven, Cumbria, is the first deep coal mine to be approved in 30 years. The site will release 0.4 megatonnes of CO2 equivalent into the atmosphere each year - not only increasing global emissions but also having a negative impact on the UK’s legally binding carbon budget unless we can stop it. The Whitehaven mine is a national, not a local issue. We need the Government to take action and overrule Cumbria County Council's decision.

attributes.action: Rescue the Economy by creating Green Jobs and scrapping investment in Fossil
attributes.background:
The government should stimulate the economy and halt the destruction of our ecosystem by creating millions of jobs in clean energy and putting carbon emissions into structural decline.

The world only has 6 months left to change the course of the climate crisis, according to the IEA.
attributes.additional_details:
Covid-19 has seen millions thrown into unemployment and at this critical point for the survival of life on earth, we must not look backwards by funding the industries that are destroying it.

The IEA has also stated that targeting green jobs will be more effective than pouring money into the high-carbon economy. Their sustainably recovery plan sets out the potential of 1.9m jobs in building efficiency, 1.1m in wind and solar power, 0.86m in power networks and millions more in other areas.

attributes.action: Add a tax onto the use of carbon
attributes.background:
Create an additional tax onto every 2 metric tons used by appliances (similar to sugar tax).
Climate Change is a monumental problem that needs addressing. By adding a small tax onto the price of carbon allows people to be more mindful of how freely they use appliances that include the use of carbon
attributes.additional_details: it is shown that 67% of pollution is caused by carbon emissions being pumped into the air by daily devices. By reducing the use of carbon it allows to find a more positive, earth- friendly alternative to allow the O-zone to heal

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We understand that you want to see new taxes on appliances that contribute to carbon emissions, but we're not sure if you want these to be applied based on the carbon cost of manufacturing appliances, or the carbon cost of using appliances.

You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do.

attributes.action: Legalise the use of privately owned electric scooters on roads and cycle paths
attributes.background: Legalise the use of privately owned electric scooters on roads and cycle paths. As we are constantly being told to use public transport less, use cars less and cut carbon emissions electric scooters are a no brainier to help with all of these issues.
attributes.additional_details: There are so many people who I know who would love to be using e-scooters for commuting and short journeys but are scared they will be stopped by police and fined £300. This makes no sense. Hire schemes are legal so what is the difference between a privately owned scooter and a hire one. Yes the speed and safety but whilst legalising them the government could make a list of safety standards to make them safer.

attributes.action: Allow the sale of clean energy Electrofuel & Biomethane cars as soon as possible
attributes.background: The Government must allow the sale of cars that run on clean energy fuels for example, Electrofuels / Efuels & Biomethane to reduce or even reverse CO2 levels. These cars should be allowed to be sold in order to reduce dependence on Lithium the extraction of which is very damaging to the environment
attributes.additional_details:
Liquid fuels will use a normal fuel pump, with no need for environmentally damaging changes to roads everywhere.
Battery manufacture creates higher co2 emissions, are expensive and will need to be replaced after only a few years.
Cobalt mining is still using Child Labour.
Biomethane can be CO2 negative full lifecycle thereby reducing carbon levels.
Biomethane is more biodiverse & can be made from waste reducing pollution.
Combustion engine cars are more affordable for those on a lower income.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We understand that you want to see more cars running on clean energy, but we're not sure exactly what you'd like the Government or Parliament to do.

Cars that use clean fuels, including non-fossil methane, are already allowed to operate in the UK. You can find out more about what fuels can be used in road vehicles here: https://www.gov.uk/guidance/fuels-for-use-in-vehicles-excise-notice-75

attributes.action: COVID-19 economic rescue plans must be green
attributes.background:
Coronavirus and climate change are the biggest challenges facing a generation.

Emergency financing must be used to build a sustainable economy which supports our health and wellbeing and drives growth, providing new jobs and opportunities across the UK for our generation and those of the future.
attributes.additional_details:
In 2019, Parliament declared a climate change emergency. 

The government committed to net-zero carbon emissions by 2050, pledging investment in clean energy solutions and green infrastructure and forecasting that the low carbon economy ‘could grow 11 per cent per year between 2015 and 2030, four times faster than the projected growth of the economy as a whole’.

The government must invest emergency funds in green and reproductive sectors including health, social care and public services.

attributes.action: Oppose 20mph speed limits on primary London borough roads
attributes.background: Establish more realistic speed limits on primary roads. A hindrance to local boroughs, slows down traffic to unrealistic level and causes more anger and frustration to local drivers.
attributes.additional_details: Drastically cutting speed limits does not improve safety nor does it drastically cut carbon emissions as constant idling is a serious issue.

rejection.details:
We can't accept your petition because the UK Government and Parliament aren't responsible for the issue you raise.

Responsibility for local roads in London is shared between Transport for London and the Greater London Authority. You could submit a petition to the Greater London Authority asking for a response from Transport for London.

You can find out more about how to petition the GLA here: https://www.london.gov.uk/mayor-assembly/london-assembly/take-part/petitions

attributes.action: DO NOT delay ANY carbon-reduction commitments on the journey to Net Zero 2050
attributes.background: Delivering Net Zero CARBON EMISSIONS by 2050 is a tough target. Notwithstanding all other pressures, this is the highest priority for our Nation's wellbeing and prosperity. Pressing actions must be taken NOW and continue WITH URGENCY throughout 2022-2050 to comply with the Environment Law (Nov 2021)
attributes.additional_details:
Less than 0.2% of the electorate voted for Liz Truss as PM. We DO NOT TRUST her pledge to 'ensure opportunity and prosperity for all people and future generations' as she diverts wildly from the commitments that elected this government into office.
Specifically, any redirection of post-CAP Land Management Scheme (ELMS) financing, designated to consolidate a long-term vision to revitalise natural resources, our land base and our agronomy will be welcoming climate change catastrophy. What a legacy

rejection.details:
We understand you would like to see the Government fulfil it's commitments to the 2050 net zero target for carbon emissions and not delay, but the target is set out in law and the Government have not outlined any changes or delay to that year as the target.

You could start a new petition which explains clearly which specific actions you would like the Government to take to achieve the 2050 target.

We currently have the below petition open on a similar theme, which you might like to sign:

Bring forward the Net Zero emissions target to 2030
